title: The Lore Team is back - and better than ever.

embed.description: Malcolm Graves is a wanted man in every realm, city-state, and empire he has visited. Tough, strong-willed, and above all relentless, through his life of crime he has amassed (then invariably lost) a small fortune. Raised in the wharf alleys of Bilgewater, Malcolm quickly learned how to fight and how to steal, skills that have served him very well over the years.

body: Seriously, you guys - all of these stories (Twisted Fate and Graves updated lore,  the Bilgewater Acts) they've been amazing. You guys went off the grid for a *long* time - but now you're here, and in your time away you didn't lose any of your story telling prowess. Welcome back... keep up the great work.

replies.body: Really well done on the Bilgewater event. :) Hope someone from the lore team sees this and pats themself on the back. I was never a fan of the champions from Bilgewater since it was so anonymous but I'm so hooked on TF and Graves now!

We've got far too much work to do to start patting ourselves on the back too much yet (plus I'm guaranteed to pop my shoulder out), but we're very glad you're enjoying the event. 

Being more into TF and Graves is precisely what we were hoping for. It means a lot for you to say that. Thank you for taking part in the fun.

Honestly, the deciding factor for me comes AFTER the event is over. I want to see whether or not you'll actually start updating the lore semi-regularly, or whether lore is still going to be relegated only to the yearly event.

I'm excited to see the hidden lore behind these champions and Tahm Kench.

Who is Ezreal's family btw?
plot twist: he's lux's long lost brother

The lore definitely adds an extra level of depth to the champions we see every day in game. When I queue up and play a game as Graves, TF, or Gangplank, I now think of the lore, think of the backstory, think of the badassery that you've revealed these characters to be involved in. I really feel that it gives players a sense that they *know* their champion - and I feel like that makes the lore an invaluable part of League of Legends.

Neither of them nor Bilgewater is part of the Lore that interested me but I really like the work you've done so far with the event, the story and so on.

I'm now looking forward to what will happen to the Shadow Isles (unless that is going to wait for when Morde gets updated) and Taric (Probably too much to ask for an even just for him but man it would be.. Outrageous)

Retcon kinda makes sense with the new lore.
Why would Graves or TF join the League? TF just wants to run away from Graves, so he has no business staying with the Institute of War. Graves might be interested if TF were in the League, but otherwise, no reason to stay. Gangplank is a ruthless leader figure of Bilgewater--also no reason to join hands with the Institute of War.

Then there's new champions like Gnar and Rek'Sai, who have no ties to any organizations to represent, or have any desires to fight.


The retcon did leave a lot of holes and Riot needs to fix them, but I don't think retcon was all bad. It did give the lore team more freedom to work with.

"TF just wants to steal shit and run away" is a one dimensional character that isn't worth a retcon.  "Graves wants revenge, despite the danger to himself trying to get it brings" is even worse.

Answering the question of why someone joined the Institute was part of what made the old lore better.

Did you even read the new lore? TF has a proper hometown and an origin story now. He was exiled because he fought for what he believed in, even though it was in conflict with people he lived with. He wants to explain to Graves what really happened. He cares about his fashion a lot.
Graves is a character hell-bent on revenge, but there's this little bits of humanity inside him, like when he gives the Piltovian bartender a silver serpent to pay for the door.

"Stealing shit and running away" is TF's core identity, and by stripping a character into just their core identity can make any developed character simple. Indiana Jones is just a treasure hunter who wants to put everything in the museum. Harry Potter is just a kid who wants to stop Voldemort. Batman is a guy who wants to take law into his own hands. Besides, it's not like the old lore was any better in this regard.


You say that explaining why a champion joined the Institute was one of the reasons why the old lore was better, but honestly they were all just either "to represent this faction"  or "to fight because of revenge/they like fighting."


Also, just to clarify, I'm not saying that retcon was a good decision.
Before retcon, each match actually meant something, unlike other MOBAs or Super Smash Bros, where characters fight for some reason? A lot of champions have lines referring to "the summoner," which gave players more immersion. That was good. Now post-retcon those are just some flavor quotes.
Despite that, some good came from retcon, although I don't know if the benefits have outweighed the costs. Post-retcon, they don't have to explain why Braum would be joining the League. They could put something like "to represent Avarosa," but then they might as well put "lorem ipsum" there instead. Instead of putting in why they joined the League, they get to put other things the champion did, like how Braum rescued a troll child stuck behind a magical door.
I'm just saying that retcon did some good, instead of all bad.

TF wanted magic, and League can help him get stronger. Graves wanted TF, and League can help him keep track of him. TF stays in the League to get stronger himself and keep a step ahead of Graves.

Characters like Gnar and Rek who have no link to the League were introduced after lore team stopped doing anything and lore was destroyed.

For Gnar and Rek'Sai, look at it from another perspective.
Those champions wouldn't have been possible before retcon without making up a shitty excuse, like Kog'Maw staying because of food.

Because Institute of War doesn't exist, League can have these characters without any ties to the Institute of War.

So because characters like Gnar and Rek don't make sense in the contest of the Institute of War, they destroy the lore and dismantle the Institute.

Then proceed to make no new lore with all this new freedom they have.
Good writers make good reasons. Not every champion had an equal stake in the League.
